NR6A1, the germ cell nuclear factor, is a superfamily of nuclear receptors. It was originally isolated from mouse cDNA libraries, but homologs have been identified in humans, frogs and fish. As no ligand has been discovered, it is designated an orphan receptor. According to evolutionary studies, only the larger transcript found in somatic cells (and apparently in all other cell types) are highly expressed.

According to the current data, clonal expansion is a prevalent feature of the B-cell repertoire in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. This process involves both resting memory B cells and activated B cell populations, which can be derived from within the bloodstream or synovial compartments, and may involve localized antigens located in the synoptics of joints.
